column4: Q. I want to allow a new person to ssh in to my computer.. I have ssh setup to allow login only with a publickey.. I placed an "authorized keys" file in the .ssh fldr of the new account, but the person cannot login.. do I have to enable something else somehwere?
yes - he sent me his public key and I put that into /home/guest/.ssh/authorized_keys
there was no .ssh dir there before so I made it
have him do 'ssh -v' on his end and see what it says. Also, the permissions on the .ssh directory you made are important. I think it has to be rwx by owner only.
ortsvorsteher  I did have a mistake.. I dint change the perms of /home/guest/.ssh
can you paste the output from 'ssh -v' from the client?
yes  http://paste.debian.net/42231/
as you can see, none of the keys offered by the client were accepted by the server. Please check that client:.ssh/id_rsa.pub matches an entry in server:~/.ssh/authorized_keys
yes - he sent me the result of ssh-keygen, which I just copied entirely to guest/.ssh/authorized_keys
time for a bigger gun. On the server, kill sshd and restart it with "-d" to get debugs from the *server* this time. And paste....
ok
I have done sudo /etc/init.d/sshd stop;  ## was thankful that I can still run my machine, since it is remote; sudo sshd -D -f /etc/ssh/sshd_config
that just means you need to type /usr/sbin/sshd. Note you want -D and -d for debugging....
http://paste.debian.net/42242/
bad ownership or modes for /home/guest ?
See this line? --->  Authentication refused: bad ownership or modes for directory /home/guest? Change permissions on /home/guest
rwx for owner, rx for group & world, then retry the ssh....
picky ssh
Well, it's *security* software. Seems ungrateful to diss it for trying to be secure....
I made the change you sugested - my partner has stepped away from his computer.. I will resume in a few minutes.. I apprecaite the feedback
I have to step out. Back in a couple of hours. I'm guessing you'll have it down by then...
